10.1016/j.mcat.2022.112179 Fig. 1 (a) Low- and (b) high-angle XRD patterns of all the catalysts. Fig 1 Fig. 2 TEM images of meso‑SnO2 and X wt% WO x /meso‑SnO2 (X = 5, 10, 15) catalysts, and TEM(HRTEM inset)-EDS mapping images of 20 wt% WO x /meso‑SnO2 and 20 wt% WO x /bulk-SnO2. Fig 2 Fig. 3 Raman spectra of meso‑SnO2, x wt% WO x /meso‑SnO2 and 20 wt% WO x /bulk-SnO2 catalysts. Fig 3 Fig. 4 H2-TPR profile of meso‑SnO2, x wt% WO x /meso‑SnO2, 20 wt% WO x /bulk-SnO2 and bulk-WO3 catalysts. Insets are the deconvolution curves of TPR profile of x wt% WO x /meso‑SnO2. Fig 4 Fig. 5 (A) Catalytic activity for the acetalization of glycerol with acetone over the prepared catalysts. (a) meso‑SnO2, (b) 5 wt% WO x /meso‑SnO2, (c) 10 wt% WO x /meso‑SnO2, (d) 15 wt% WO x /meso‑SnO2, (e) 20 wt% WO x /meso‑SnO2, (f) 20 wt% WO x /bulk-SnO2. Reaction conditions: molar ratio of glycerol to acetone = 1:30, reaction temperature = 20 °C, catalyst amount = 0.05 g (5 wt% glycerol), reaction time = 2 h. (B) Relationship between the catalytic performances and the number of acidic sites. Fig 5 Fig. 6 Effect of (a) reaction temperature, (b) reaction time, (c) molar ratio of glycerol to acetone, and (d) catalyst amount on acetalization of glycerol over the 20 wt% WO x /meso‑SnO2. Optimal reaction conditions: molar ratio of glycerol to acetone = 1:30, catalyst amount = 0.05 g (5 wt% glycerol), reaction time = 2 h. Fig 6 Fig. 7 Acetalization of glycerol with (a) benzaldehyde and (b) furfural over 20 wt% WO x /meso‑SnO2 catalyst at different reaction temperatures. Reaction conditions: molar ratio of glycerol to benzaldehyde or furfural = 1:5, catalyst amount = 0.05 g (5 wt% glycerol), reaction time = 1 h. Fig 7 Fig. 8 Recycle test of the 20 wt% WO x /meso‑SnO2 catalyst without any treatment. Reaction conditions: molar ratio of glycerol to acetone = 1:30, reaction temperature = 20 °C, catalyst amount = 0.05 g (5 wt% glycerol), reaction time = 1 h. Fig 8 Fig. 9 (a) and (b) Effect of weight hourly space velocity (WHSV, h − 1) on acetalization of glycerol with acetone over 20 wt% WO x /meso‑SnO2 catalyst. Reaction conditions: molar ratio of glycerol to acetone = 1:30, reaction temperature = 30 °C, catalyst amount = 0.2 g, reaction time = 24 h. Fig 9 Scheme 1 Acetalization of glycerol with acetone to yield (2,2-dimethyl-1,3-dioxolan-4-yl) methanol (solketal) and 2,2-dimethyl-1,3-dioxan-5-ol (acetal). Scheme 1 Scheme 2 (a) The acetalization of glycerol with benzaldehyde to yield 1,3-dioxolane and 1,3-dioxane; (b) The acetalization of glycerol with furfural to yield (2-(furan-2-yl)−1,3-dioxolan-4-yl)methanol and 2-(furan-2-yl)−1,3-dioxan-5-ol. Scheme 2 Table 1 Physical properties of all the catalysts. Ordered WO x /mesoporous SnO2 catalysts with excellent acetalization performance for producing bio-additives from glycerol Chen Shen Conceptualization Investigation Data curation Writing – original draft a 1 Zhengyang Li Conceptualization Investigation Data curation Writing – original draft b 1 Jin Seo Park Investigation Formal analysis b Zhenghua Li Investigation Formal analysis b Chengbin Li Investigation Formal analysis b Gyoung Hee Hong Investigation b Jungho Lee Investigation b Hyeonji Moon Investigation b Ji Man Kim Conceptualization Supervision Writing – review & editing Funding acquisition b ⁎ Mingshi Jin Conceptualization Supervision Writing – review & editing Funding acquisition a ⁎ a Department of Chemistry, Yanbian University, Yanji 133002, Jilin Province, China Department of Chemistry Yanbian University Yanji Jilin Province 133002 China aDepartment of Chemistry, Yanbian University, Yanji 133002, Jilin Province, China b Department of Chemistry, Sungkyunkwan University, Suwon, 440-746, Republic of Korea Department of Chemistry Sungkyunkwan University Suwon 440-746 Republic of Korea bDepartment of Chemistry, Sungkyunkwan University, Suwon, 440-746, Republic of Korea ⁎ Corresponding author. 1 These authors contributed equally. Highly ordered WO x /mesoporous SnO2 (WO x /meso‑SnO2) catalysts with varying WO x loadings of (5 ∼ 20) wt% displaying excellent catalytic performance were demonstrated in the acetalization of glycerol with acetone. The synthesized catalysts were analyzed using various techniques including X-ray diffraction, N2-isotherm, electron microscopy, H2 temperature programmed reduction, raman spectroscopy, and thermogravimetric analysis. For the acetalization of glycerol with acetone, the most active catalyst was found to be WO x /meso‑SnO2 with 20 wt% WO x , and the maximum conversion of glycerol (100%) was obtained after 2 h at 20 °C, providing 97.4% selectivity (97.4% yield) for the five-membered product (solketal), due to the presence of a large number of acidic sites on the surface of the catalyst. The catalytic activity of 20 wt% WO x /meso‑SnO2 was also studied in a flow reactor. Tests were carried out at 30 °C, acetone/glycerol=30, WHSV=(4 or 8) h − 1, and atmospheric pressure for 24 h. The catalytic results showed that, when the WHSV was 4 h − 1, after 24 h of time-on-stream, both the glycerol conversion of (100 to 97.9)% and solketal yield of (97.5 to 93.6)% slightly decreased. This result suggests the potential of the 20 wt% WO x /meso‑SnO2 catalyst for the industrial acetalization of glycerol. Graphic abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Mesoporous WO x /SnO2 Glycerol acetalization Re-usability Batch-type reactor Continuous flow process 1.Introduction Biodiesel, an important type of renewable fuel with clear benefits relative to diesel fuel, has been widely produced by the transesterification of vegetable oils or animal fats with methanol [1]. In this process, glycerol is formed as a by-product and accounts for one-tenth of every gallon of diesel produced [2]. Due to its low cost and availability, glycerol has been utilized for applications in the pharmaceutical, food, beverage, tobacco, petrochemical feedstock, and fuel industries [3]. However, due to saturation of the glycerol market, the high volume of glycerol is currently considered a waste product. Therefore, it is of great significance to convert the excess glycerol into other value-added chemicals, and improve the utilization rate of glycerol and the commercialization of biodiesel [4]. Viable conversion processes include oxidation [5], acetalization [6], hydrogenolysis [7], etherification [8], dehydration [9], esterification [10] and reformation [11]. Among these processes, acetalization is one of the most important methods for the synthesis of green and cost-effective bio-additive chemicals from glycerol [4]. In acetalization reactions, glycerol acetals and ketals are produced by the acid-catalyzed reaction of glycerol with ketones or aldehydes. When reacting glycerol with ketone, the ketal with a five-membered ring is as the main product, whereas reactions with aldehydes produce a mixture of five- and six-membered cyclic acetals [12]. These products are widely used as solvents, surfactants, protecting agents, plasticizers, scents, and flavors in several industries [13–15]. For example, solketal (2,2-dimethyl-1,3-dioxolane-4-methol) is formed via an acetalization reaction between glycerol and acetone, which has been directly used as a fuel additive to reduce particulate emission (particles, hydrocarbons, etc.) to improve the cold properties and reduce the viscosity of diesel and gasoline [16,17]. Traditionally, the acetalization of glycerol has been carried out using mineral acids such as H2SO4, HCl, HF, and H3PO4 as homogeneous catalysts [18,19]. However, it is difficult to separate and regenerate these homogeneous catalysts from the reaction system, which leads to large amounts of waste. Hence, to overcome these problems, several heterogeneous catalysts have been studied, which include zeolites [20], mixed metal oxides [14,21], supported metal oxides [22], and Amberlyst [23], which have various advantages over homogeneous catalysts, such as ready separability, good stability, and regenerability. SnO2-based heterogeneous catalysts have been studied in various reactions, due to SnO2 possessing unique chemical and mechanical stability, as well as two specific characteristics: oxygen vacancy defects, and variations in valence state [24,25]. Ma et al. found that due to the strong interaction between WO3 and SnO2, SnO2 with WO3 as a solid acid catalyst was more effective than pure WO3 or SnO2 for the hydrolysis of dichlordifluoromethane [26] . Sarkar et al. investigated a new mesoporous catalyst SnO2/WO3 with high surface area, which effectively catalyzed oleic acid esterification and could be reused several times without loss of catalytic performance [27]. Mallesham et al. reported the synthesis of solketal from glycerol using Mo- and W-promoted SnO2 solid acid catalysts, in which, due to its redox properties and superior lattice defectsthe Mo6+- doped SnO2 showed better catalytic activity than W6+- doped SnO: glycerol conversion and solketal selectivity were (61 and 96)% for MoO3/SnO2 and (55 and 96)% for WO3/SnO2, respectively [21]. Although WO3/SnO2 has been reported for this reaction, it did not provide better catalytic activity. In addition, the acetalization studies were undertaken in batch reactors using homogeneous or heterogeneous catalysts with mechanical stirring. Mechanical stirrers can improve poorly defined interfacial areas, and the yield of product is influenced by stirring intensity and efficiency. However, scale-up in a batch process is limited. Therefore, using a continuous flow process to produce solketal over heterogeneous catalysts has advantages of high heat and mass transfer efficiency, such as for scale-up from laboratory to industrial scale [28]. Accordingly, Nanda et al. studied a new continuous flow process to synthesize solketal using heterogeneous catalysts (e.g., zeolite, Amberlyst dry, Amberlyst wet, zirconium sulfate) under different reaction conditions, with maximum solketal yield (88%) being obtained at 40 °C, 600 psi, WHSV of 4 h − 1, with acetone / glycerol molar ratio of 6:1 [29]. In the present work, highly ordered mesoporous SnO2 support was prepared by a hard templating method from the KIT-6 template, and mesoporous WO x /SnO2 catalysts with large surface areas in both batch type and continuous flow processes to examine the acetalization of glycerol with acetone to yield 2,2-dimethyl-1,3-dioxolane-4-methanol (solketal) under solvent-free conditions. The influence of reaction parameters, such as the molar ratio of reactants, catalyst loading, reaction temperature/time, weight hourly space velocity and recycle experiment were studied. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of KIT-6 template Ordered mesoporous silica KIT-6 with cubic Ia3d mesostructures was synthesized according to the reported procedure [30], which was used as the silica template to synthesize mesoporous SnO2 materials. For this, 30.0 g of pluronic triblock copolymer P123 (EO20PO70EO20, M w = 5800, Aldrich) was dissolved in a mixture of 1085 g of distilled water, 30.0 g of n-butanol (99.7 wt%, Samchun), and 59.0 g of hydrochloric acid (c-HCl, 35 wt%, Samchun). The resulting solution was vigorously stirred at 35 °C for 1 h, followed by the addition of 64.5 g of tetraethylorthosilicate (TEOS, 98%, Aldrich). The obtained mixture was vigorously stirred at 35 °C for another 24 h, and then kept under static conditions at 100 °C for 24 h in an oven. The white product was then filtered, washed with distilled water, and dried at 80 °C overnight. After that, the powder was washed with EtOH and filtered, then dried at 80 °C for 12 h. Finally, the product was finally calcined at 550 °C for 3 h to remove the P123 template. 2.2 Synthesis of mesoporous SnO2 Mesoporous SnO2 material (meso‑SnO2) was prepared by a nano-replication method using the mesoporous silica KIT-6 as a hard template. For a typical synthesis of mesoporous SnO2, 5.0 g of KIT-6 was heated at 373 K for 1 h and 5.06 g of SnCl2 • 2H2O (98%, Aldrich) was melted to a liquid state at 373 K, and then impregnated into the silica template. The composite material was shaken for 4 times over 1 h (shaken for one minute every 15 min), and dried in an oven at 80 °C overnight, to let the precursor spontaneously infiltrate into the mesopores of the silica template. The composite material was then calcined at 700 °C for 3 h under static air conditions. After the heat treatment, the silica template was removed from the composite material by treatment with 20 wt% hydrofluoric acid (HF) solution. The resulting solid product (meso‑SnO2) was washed with distilled water and acetone several times, and then dried at 80 °C overnight in an oven. 2.3 Preparation of WO x /SnO2 catalysts For comparison, the supported WO x /meso‑SnO2 and WO x /bulk-SnO2 (commercial SnO2, Sigma-Aldrich) catalysts were prepared by an incipient wetness impregnation method with the required amount of aqueous ammonium metatungstate solution ((NH4)6H2W12O40•xH2O, 66.5 wt%, Aldrich). For synthesis of the catalyst with 20 wt% loading, 0.266 g of (NH4)6H2W12O40•xH2O was dissolved in distilled water, then impregnated into 1.0 g of meso‑SnO2 or commercial SnO2 at ambient temperature. After drying at 80 °C overnight, the obtained products were calcinated under static air conditions for 3 h at 400 °C. For meso‑SnO2 support, the catalysts with different WO x of (5, 10 and 15) wt% loadings were also prepared by the same method. 2.4 Characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were obtained using the reflection mode of a Rigaku D /MAX-2200 diffractometry employing Cu K α radiation (λ = 1.54 Å) at 30 kV and 40 mA. N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms were obtained using a Micromeritics Tristar system at liquid N2 temperature. Prior to measurements, all samples were completely dried under vacuum at 323 K for 12 h. The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) and Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) methods were utilized to calculate the BET surface area and pore size distribution. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images were obtained by Hitachi UHR S 5500 FE-SEM operating at an accelerating voltage of 30 kV. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were collected using a JEOL JEM 3010 at an accelerating voltage of 300 kV. Raman spectra were recorded under ambient conditions at room temperature (RT) using a WITEC Alpha300. H2-Temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) was performed in a fixed-bed reactor. A 20 mg sample was placed in a quartz microreactor and pretreated with He up to 100 °C at a rate of 10 °C min−1 for 1 h. After pretreatment, 10 vol% H2 in a He flow of 40 ml / min was applied at RT, and maintained for 30 min. Finally, the sample temperature was ramped up to 900 °C at 10 °C min−1. The acidities of the catalysts were examined by using ammonia-temperature-programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) conducted from RT to 700 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min. A quantity of 20 mg of the catalyst was placed in a quartz tube, and heated to 473 K under a flow of He gas for 1 h. The adsorption of NH3 on the catalyst surface was conducted by flowing 4.9 wt% NH3/He gas for 1 h at RT. After removing the physically adsorbed NH3 by purging the sample with He at RT for 1 h, the samples were heated from RT to 700 °C. The desorbed NH3 gas was treated with 100 mL of 0.02 M HCl aqueous solution. The amount of acid site was then determined by titration of HCl solution with 0.02 M NaOH solution. FT-IR spectra were carried out by Bruker IFS-66/S spectrometry. Raman spectra were recorded under ambient conditions at RT using a WITEC Alpha300. The excitation line of the laser was 532 nm. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was carried out by DSC-TGA (STA 7200, Hitachi Thermal Analyzer) instrument at a heating rate of 10 °C/min from 50 °C to 700 °C under air flow conditions. 2.5 Acetalization of glycerol The catalytic performance of synthesized catalysts was examined for the acetalization of glycerol with acetone, benzaldehyde, and furfural. The reactions were carried out in a 50 mL two-necked flask fitted with a reflux condenser. Typically, 1.0 g of glycerol, and 19.8 g of acetone (molar ratio 1:30) were added into the flask. The reaction mixture was vigorously stirred at 20 °C in a water bath for 5 min, followed by the addition of 0.05 g of catalyst (5 wt% glycerol). The reaction products were withdrawn every 15 min, and analyzed by gas chromatography-flame ionization detector (GC-FID). In a continuous flow process, the synthesis of solketal was carried out in a fixed-bed quartz reactor (10.21 mm OD, 6.85 mm ID) at atmospheric pressure (RT 30 °C). Before initiating the reaction, 0.20 g of catalyst was preloaded into the catalytic bed. The reaction mixture of reactants (glycerol: acetone = 1: 30, molar ratio) as the feed was pumped into the reactor using a micro pump (SSI LabAlliance) at a specific flow rate. The feeding rate was determined by the selected weight hourly space velocity (WHSV, reciprocal of reaction time) and the amount of the catalyst used in the reaction. The following formulas were used to define the WHSV (Eq. (1)) and space time yield (STY) (Eq. (2)). (1) WHSV ( h − 1 ) = flow of glycerol per hour ( g / h ) weight of catalyst ( g ) (2) STY ( g − solketal / g − cat / h ) = weight of solketal ( g ) weight of catalyst ( g ) * reaction time ( h ) After reaction, the catalyst was removed from the reaction mixture using a disposable filter (DISMIC-13HP020AN filter, Advantec), and analyzed by gas chromatography-flame ionization detector (GC-FID) equipped with an HP-5 capillary column (30 m × 0.32 mm inner diameter × 1.0 μm film thickness). The glycerol conversion (Eq. (3)) and selectivity of solketal (Eq. (4)) are defined as follows: (3) Conversion ( % ) = amount of glycerol converted ( mole ) initial amount of glycerol ( mole ) × 100 (4) Selectivity ( % ) = amount of glycerol converted to a product ( mole ) total amount of glycerol converted ( mole ) × 100 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization The mesoporous silica template KIT-6 with 3D cubic Ia3d mesostructure was confirmed from the low-angle XRD pattern, as shown in Fig. S1a of the Supplementary Information (SI). The low-angle pattern exhibited [211], [220] and [332] planes that are characteristic of cubic Ia3d symmetry [31]. In Fig. S1b of the SI, the N2-adsorption-desorption isotherms of KIT-6 depict a typical type-Ⅳ isotherm with H1-type hysteresis loops, and the corresponding pore size distribution curve was obtained from the adsorption branches by the BJH method. The BET surface area, total pore volume and pore size of KIT-6 were 705 m2/g, 0.81 cm3/g and 7.2 nm, respectively. Fig. 1 shows the low- and high-angle XRD patterns of the pure ordered mesoporous SnO2, X wt% WO x /meso‑SnO2 (X = 5, 10, 15, and 20), and 20 wt% WO x/bulk-SnO2 materials. The low-angle XRD patterns (Fig. 1a) indicated that the mesosturcture of all the WO x /meso‑SnO2 materials were similar to that of the KIT-6 silica template. However, a new peak appeared for all of the materials, corresponding to the position of the (110) plane. The presence of the new (110) diffraction peak indicates that after the silica template etching process, the mesostructure of cubic Ia3d was transformed into tetragonal I41/a (or lower symmetry) [32]. The high-angle XRD patterns depict the framework crystallinity of all the materials, as shown in Fig. 1b. The diffraction peaks of all the samples with 2θ values corresponding to the (110), (101), (200), (211), (220), (002), (310), (112), (301), (202), and (321) planes exhibited the typical tetragonal phase of SnO2 (JCPDS 88–0287, P42/mnm). In addition, no XRD peaks corresponding to tungsten species were observed for the WO x /meso‑SnO2 materials, suggesting the formation of the amorphous phase or highly dispersed very small particle size of WO x and presence of strong interactions between WO x and SnO2. In contrast to the meso‑SnO2 support, WO3 crystalline bulk phase formed on the commercial SnO2 support due to its low surface area (11 m2/g), which reveals that the use of meso‑SnO2 with a special high surface area is beneficial for particle dispersions. The crystallite sizes of all of the samples were determined by Scherrer's equation, and Table 1 presents the obtained values. The data show that the crystallite sizes of WO x /meso‑SnO2 catalysts gradually decreased with increasing WO x loading, which is probably because WO x on the surface may inhibited the particle agglomeration of pure meso‑SnO2 during the sintering process due to the cooperative nature of the cations of the mixed oxides. The strong mutual interaction between metal oxides can prevent their crystallization and particle growth, resulting in higher specific areas than recalcinated meso‑SnO2 [33,34]. However, with the same content of WO x on commercial SnO2 support, the crystalline size of 20 wt% WO x /bulk-SnO2 was around 50 nm. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and pore size distributions of synthesized the catalysts are shown in Fig. S2. Pure meso‑SnO2 and all the WO x /meso‑SnO2 materials exhibit type-Ⅳ isotherms with H1 hysteresis loops in the range of p/po = (0.5 - 1.0), characteristic of a mesoporous material, as shown in Fig. S2a. The corresponding narrow pore size distribution curves of all of the materials (Fig.S2b), obtained from the adsorption branches of the N2-sorption isotherms, indicate that the materials have dual pore structures. The small pores should come from the silica frameworks after removal of the silica template, and the larger pores likely originate the phase-transformation from the cubic Ia3d mesostructure to the tetragonal I41/a (or lower) mesostructure. As shown in Table 1, after loading different amounts of WO x on the meso‑SnO2 support, the surface areas, pore volumes and pore sizes of samples were decreased, probably due to the partial pore blockage by the impregnated WO x . However, the WO x /meso‑SnO2 materials exhibited a higher specific surface area than the recalcinated meso‑SnO2 (73 m2/g) due to the strong mutual interaction between WO x and SnO2 preventing crystallization and particle growth. In addition, WO x loaded on commercial SnO2 exhibited the lowest surface area (7 m2/g). TEM images (Fig. 2 ) confirms that the meso‑SnO2 and all of the WO x /meso‑SnO2 materials showed a highly ordered mesostructure that was composed of uniform nanometer-sized particles, suggesting that after WO x loading, no obvious changes exist in the frameworks after WO x loading. Energy-dispersive spectrocopic (EDS) mapping images of 20 wt% WO x /meso‑SnO2 revealed that the tungsten atoms in the WO x /meso‑SnO2 material were homogeneously dispersed over the whole particles. In contrast, the 20 wt% WO x /bulk-SnO2 formed a large particle of the aggregate WO x on the surface of bulk SnO2, as shown in the right EDS mapping images at right. The well-developed crystalline framework of 20 wt% WO x /meso‑SnO2 was also observed in the HR-TEM images (insets of TEM images), and the d -spacings of (3.41 and 2.63) Å are corresponding to the (110) and (101) planes of the tetragonal phase of SnO2. However, WO x dispersed on the surface of commerical SnO2 produced a crystallized WO3 grain in a certain area around SnO2. The fringe spacing of 3.72 Å was indexed to the (020) plane of the orthorombic WO3 phase [35]. Raman spectrospcopy is an important technique for identifying the existing states of tungsten and tin oxide. Fig. 3 shows the Raman spectra of pure tin oxide and WO x /SnO2 materials. The spectrum of meso‑SnO2 showed the bands at around 476 cm−1 (E g), 633 cm−1 (A 1g), and 774 cm−1 (B 2g) that could be assigned to the tetragonal structure of SnO2 [36]. After loading tungsten species, a new band at around 950 ∼ 980 cm−1 appreared in the WO x /meso‑SnO2 materials, representing the stretching mode of W = O species on the surface [37, 38]. When the WO x content reached 20 wt%, the new band shifted from 950 cm−1 to 980 cm−1 , due to the surface monooxo tungsten species (υs (W = O)) tending to form polyoxotungstate species [39,40]. The 20 wt% WO x /bulk-SnO2 material produced three new bands at approximately 272, 707, and 815 cm−1, which can be assigned to the symmetric and asymmetric stretching vibrations of W-O-W modes of crystalline WO3 phase, as observed from XRD and TEM measurements [41]. FT-IR (Fig. S3) spectra displayed the characteristic peaks of pure meso‑SnO2 and WO x /SnO2 materials. The band at 1621 cm−1 was assigned to the bending vibrations of hydrogen-bonded surface OH groups of physically adsorbed water molecules [42]. The peaks around 651 and 553 cm−1 were assigned to different stretching vibrations of the O-Sn-O and Sn-O-Sn groups, respectively [43]. Upon loading WO x , a new band appeared at ∼ 970 cm−1 that was assigned to the stretching modes of W-O or W = O bonds. Compared to pure SnO2, the existence of a Sn-O-W bond at 871 cm−1 indicates the presence of an interaction between highly dispersed WO x and meso‑SnO2 [21]. NH3-TPD analysis was undertaken to estimate the acidic properties of the catalysts. As shown in Fig. S4, NH3 desorption peaks appeared in both lower-temperature region (100–200 °C) and higher-temperature region (450–600 °C), implying that the acidic center of all the catalysts are related to weak-strong acid sites. The 20 wt%/meso‑SnO2 shows relatively higher amount of NH3 desorption peak compared to other catalysts and the higher NH3-desorption may enhance the its catalytic performance. Though NH3-TPD analysis provides much information about the strength and amount of the acid sites, it doesn't afford sufficient evidences about the nature of the acidic sites. For this,we performed FT-IR spectroscopic studies of pyridine over the catalysts. In the pyridine FT-IR spectra (Fig. S5), there is only Lewis acid sites exist on the surface of mesoporous SnO2. After loading WO x on the surface of mesoporous SnO2, both BrØnsted and Lewis acid sites exist on the surface of catalyst. As the WO x content increases, the acid sites increases and the BrØnsted acid sites appear from 15% WO x /meso‑SnO2. The reason is increasing the amount of WO x , tungstate monomeric species (Lewis acidic sites) tending to form dimeric-tungstate species (BrØnsted acidic sites, polymeric species) on the surface of meso‑SnO2 as shown in the Raman spectra (Fig. 3). Moreover, both BrØnsted and Lewis acid sites all contributed to the reaction. Fig. 4 shows H2-TPR profiles of the catalysts. Bulk WO3 exhibited two high intensity peaks of consumed hydrogen beginning at 600 °C and centered at 780 and 840 °C. It is important to note that these peaks might be assigned to the stepwise reduction of WO3 to W(0) [WO3 (VI) → W20O58(V, VI) → WO2(IV) → W(0)] [44]. The H2-TPR profile for meso‑SnO2 exhibited mainly a reduction peak at about 654 °C, which was assigned to the reduction of Sn(4+)→ Sn(2+)→Sn(0). According to Wachs et al. [45], octahedrally-coordinated WO x species are reduced at temperatures from 300 to 600 °C through intermediate oxidation states. Thus, the first peak in the WO x /meso‑SnO2 catalyst spectra could be assigned to the multiple step reduction of octahedrally-coordinated WO x species. The first reduction peaks shifted to lower temperature with increasing WO x content due to the size growth of WO x domains. Vermaire and van Berge [46] reported that the reduction peak appearing at higher temperature in W/A samples with monolayer tungsten loading can be attributed to the W6+→ W0 reduction of tetrahedrally-coordinated amorphous WO x species. A similar result was reported by Horsley et al. [47], who found that isolated and dimeric WO x tetrahedral species were difficult to reduce and the reduction peaks appeared at higher temperature. Thus, the reduction peaks in WO x /meso‑SnO2 catalysts located at 740–900 °C can probably be attributed to the further reduction of partially reduced WO x species (W4+ → W0) formed in the first reduction peak, together with reduction of tetrahedrally-coordinated WO x species [48]. The overlapping reduction peaks in the TPR profiles of xWO x /meso‑SnO2 were deconvoluted (Fig. 4 inset data). In the WO x /bulk-SnO2 catalyst, the first reduction peak shifted to higher temperature, and the peaks were similar to the bulk WO3 reduction peaks due to the formation of crystalline WO3 on the surface of the commercial SnO2 support. The H2-TPR results indicate that the amount of W loading influences catalyst reducibility, and the difference in redox behavior between the WO x /SnO2 materials and pure SnO2 reflects the existence of interactions between the SnO2 support and WO x species. 3.2 Acetalization of glycerol over different catalysts Scheme 1 shows that the acetalization of glycerol with acetone produces two products: (2,2-dimethyl-1,3-dioxolan-4-yl)methanol (solketal), and 2,2-dimethyl-1,3-dioxan-5-ol as shown in Scheme 1. According to many proposed mechanisms for the acetalization reaction, the role of acid catalyst (Brønsted / Lewis acid sites) is to activate the acetone molecule for nucleophilic addition of glycerol to form a hemiketal. The hemiketal (adsorbed over acidic sites) undergoes dehydroxylation, producing a tertiary carbonium ion intermediate, which reacts (nucleophilic attack) with the secondary hydroxyl group to form the five-membered ring ketal (solketal) or with the tertiary hydroxyl group to form the six-membered ring ketal (acetal) [20, 49, 50]. The catalytic performances of the meso‑SnO2 and WO x /SnO2 catalysts were studied for the glycerol acetalization with acetone, and the reactions were carried out at 20 °C under solvent-free conditions with a 1:30 molar ratio of glycerol to acetone for 2 h. Fig. 5 A and Table 2 show that after loading WO x, the conversions of glycerol were significantly enhanced, and increasing the amount of WO x increased the catalytic activity. The glycerol conversion over the meso‑SnO2, and 5, 10, 15, and 20 wt% WO x /meso‑SnO2 catalysts was found to be 36, and 41.2, 82, 99, and 100%, and the calculated STY of solketal over these catalysts was 3.2, 3.7, 8.8, 12.9, 14.0 g-solketal/g-cat/h, respectively. It is clear that 20wt% WO x /meso‑SnO2 catalyst shows the highest STY of solketal. Fig. 5B shows the relationship between the catalytic performance and the amount of acidic sites that were determined by the titration of adsorbed ammonia (Table 2), indicating that the glycerol conversion linearly correlates with the number of acidic sites. The selectivity of 5-membered solketal is comparatively higher than that of the six-membered acetal, due to the axial methyl group in the chair conformation repulsively interacting with the two hydrogen atoms in the other axial positions of the six-membered ring leading the 5-membered solketal to be thermodynamically more stable than the 6-membered acetal [51]. Among the catalysts, 20 wt% WO x /meso‑SnO2 catalyst with a greater number of acidic sites results in 100% of glycerol conversion and 97.4% of solketal selectivity. Thus, a higher number of acidic sites is beneficial for the glycerol conversion and solketal selectivity. The enhanced acidic sites of the catalysts might result from two properties: (1) First, the mixed oxides exhibited much stronger acidic properties than the single oxide, which is probably due to an excess of negative charge or positive charge caused by the presence of non-equivalent Sn-O-W bonds [21]; (2) Second, it was formed tungstate monomeric species (Lewis acidic sites) and dimeric-tungstate species (BrØnsted acidic sites, polymeric species) were formed on the surface of SnO2 after loading WO x [52,53]. Compared to the 20 wt% WO x /meso‑SnO2, the use of the commercial SnO2 as support, led to comparatively lower glycerol conversion (50.2%) and solketal selectivity (63.3%), which could be ascribed to the lower number of catalytically active acidic sites and lower surface area. Most catalytic reactions occur on the surface of the catalysts, and the reaction rate is typically proportional to the surface area of the catalysts. Therefore, high surface area of catalyst is one of the primary reasons for achieving better catalytic activity in the acetalization of glycerol with acetone. 3.3 Optimized reaction conditions for the acetalization of glycerol In order to investigate the effect of reaction temperature on the acetalization of glycerol with acetone, a series of experiments was performed over 20 wt% WO x /meso‑SnO2 catalyst. Fig. 6 a shows the remarkable increases of the conversion of glycerol and selectivity for solketal product with increasing the reaction temperature from 0 °C to 30 °C. A 100% glycerol conversion was observed at (20 and 30) °C after 2 h, and the solketal selectivity values of (97.4 and 97.8)% at (20 and 30) °C, respectively, were similar. Therefore, 20 °C was chosen as the optimal reaction temperature in this work. The kinetics for acetalization of glycerol with acetone at different temperatures (0 °C, 10 °C, 20 °C, and 30 °C) were also studied (Fig. S6). The rate constants for the apparent consumption of glycerol were obtained from the pseudo-first-order equation: ln (C0/Ct) = ƙt (where C0 and Ct are the glycerol concentrations at time zero and time t (min), ƙ is the rate constant). The apparent rate constants of glycerol were 0.0117, 0.0367, and 0.0523 min−1 at 0 °C, 20 °C, and 30 °C. As shown in Fig. S6 (a), a plot of ln (Ct/Co) versus reaction time (t) displayed a linear relationship that confirmed the pseudo-first order reaction kinetics. The apparent rate constants of glycerol were 0.0117, 0.0367 and 0.0523 min−1 at 273 K, 283 K and 293 K, respectively. From the reaction rates at different temperatures, the apparent activation energy for acetalization of the glycerol was derived from the Arrhenius equation: Ea= RT2 (ԁ lnƙ/dT) (Ea is the apparent activation energy, R and T are the gas constant and reaction temperature). Through the Arrhenius plot as shown in Fig. S6 (b), the activation energy for acetalization of glycerol with acetone is 50.12 kJ/mol. The activation energy for the glycerol ketalization of H-BEA zeolite has been reported to be 44.77 kJ/mol and 164.34 kJ/mol in the temperature range 60–80 °C and 25–60 °C, respectively [54, 55]. Ruffo et al. reported value of activation energy around 96 kJ/mol for the homogeneous catalyst [56]. Indeed, the Ea of the present catalyst is low compared to several catalysts reported in the literature, indicating that the catalyst exhibits good catalytic activity. Fig. 6b shows the influence of time-on-stream on the glycerol conversion and solketal selectivity over 20 wt% WO x /meso‑SnO2 catalyst at 20 °C. The glycerol conversion was 89.3, 96.2, 99.5 and 99.7% at 15, 30, 45, and 60 min, respectively. After 2 h, 100% glycerol conversion was obtained, a slight enhancement glycerol conversion (100%) and solketal selectivity (97.4%) being obtained at 60 min (96.1%). The selectivity of solketal increasing with time is possibly due to the dioxane getting rearranged to dioxalane [57]. Fig. 6c shows the influence of the molar ratio of glycerol to acetone on the catalytic performace of 20 wt% WO x /meso‑SnO2 catalyst. The reactions were carried out at 20 °C with different reactant molar ratios of (1:2, 1:5, 1:10, 1:15, 1:20 and 1:30. The obtained results clearly show that increasing the amount of acetone, the equilibrium conversion obliviously increases, and 100% glycerol conversion was observed at 1:30, which equilibrium constant is nerar to 1. The selectivity of solketal with a slight increase from (96.3 to 97.4)% as the molar ratio increased. Therefore, it can be concluded that the glycerol conversion strongly depends on the molar ratio of acetone to glycerol. Based on these results, the molar ratio of 1:30 was found to be optimal for converting glycerol into solketal. In order to test the catalytic ability of 20 wt% WO x /meso‑SnO2 catalyst in the continuous-flow reactor, the molar ratio of 1:30 was also chosen as the optimum condition because glycerol can completely dissolve in acetone, and the reactant liquid can successfully pass through the reactor at atmospheric pressure. The effect of catalyst amount on the acetalization reaction was studied by varying the 20 wt% WO x /meso‑SnO2 catalyst content from (0.01 to 0.10) g. The reaction temperature, time, and molar ratio of glycerol to acetone were 20 °C, 1 h, and 1:30, respectively. Fig. 6d, shows that with increased catalyst amount up to 0.05 g, the glycerol conversion and solketal selectivity revealed a significant increase. At 5 wt% (0.05 g) of catalyst, the glycerol conversion and selectivity for solketal were (100 and 97.4)%, respectively. Furthermore, with further increases in catalyst amount, there was no significant increase or decrease in glycerol conversion or solketal selectivity. The glycerol conversion and selectivity of solketal with (0.08 and 0.1) g of catalyst were (99.5 and 97.5) and (99.3 and 97.4)%, respectively. These results indicate that an excess amount of acidic sites (i.e., catalyst amount) is not necessary, probably because an equilibrium conversion is already reached with 0.05 g of catalyst. Fig. 7 shows the catalytic efficiency of 20 wt% WO x /meso‑SnO2 catalyst for the acetalization of glycerol with benzaldehyde and furfural (Scheme 2) that was investigated as shown in Fig. 7. The reactions were performed under the same reaction conditions: solvent-free, benzaldehyde (or furfural)/glycerol molar ratio = 5:1, different reaction temperatures (20 °C, 40 °C, and 60 °C), and 5 wt% of catalyst. Fig. 7a shows the results of acetalization of glycerol with benzaldehyde for 1 h at different reaction temperatures. It was found that with increasing reaction temperature, the glycerol conversion increased. The Glycerol conversion at (20, 40, and 60) °C was found to be (86.7, 91.5, and 97.7)%, respectively. However, the selectivity of 1,3-dioxolane decreased from (94.4 to 88.1)%, which is probably due to isomerization of the 5-membered acetal to the 6-membered acetal, as reported by Mallesham et al. [58]. Fig. 7b shows the results of the acetalization of glycerol with furfural at different reaction temperatures. The conversion of glycerol at (20, 40, and 60) °C was (87.4, 90.5 and 90.7)%, and the selectivity for 5-membered acetals was (84.0, 83.8, and 83.9)%, respectively. 3.4 Recyclability of 20 wt% WOx/meso‑SnO2 catalyst One of the main advantages of heterogeneous catalysts is the convenience of separation and their reuse in successive catalytic cycles. The reusability analysis of the 20 wt% WO x /meso‑SnO2 catalyst for the acetalization of glycerol with acetone was also studied under the same reaction conditions. After each run, the used catalyst was separated from the reaction mixture by centrifugation, and without any treatment (i.e. solvent washing and recalcination). Then, fresh glycerol and acetone were directly added into the round-bottom flask for the next run. Fig. 8 shows that the glycerol conversion decreased slightly from (100 to 98.1)%, and after 7 recycles, the selectivity of solketal decreased from (97.8 to 96.4)%, which might be due to some used catalyst loss in the filtration process, and to adsorbed organic species on the surface of the catalyst. The characterization of the used catalyst shown in Fig. S7. The post-catalytic sample with 20wt% WOx/meso‑SnO2 was still maintains a good mesoporous structure and with uniform nano-meter sized particles. Therefore, there is no obvious change to the frameworks after reaction. 3.5 Continuous flow reactor testing with of 20 wt% WOx/meso‑SnO2 catalyst Fig. S8 shows the catalytic stability for 20 wt% WO x /meso‑SnO2 catalyst over a longer time-on-stream investigated under a simple flow continuous operation. Experiments were conducted under different WHSV of (4.0 and 8.0) h − 1, while keeping other reaction parameters constant (30 °C, acetone/glycerol molar ratio of 30, 24 h time-on-stream). For a WHSV of 4 h − 1, the glycerol conversion of (98.7 ± 1)%, solketal selectivity of (96.9 ± 2)% and solketal yield of (95.7 ± 2)% were slightly decreased after 24 h time-on-stream, as shown in Fig. 9 a. In contrast, with an increase in WHSV from (4 to 8) h − 1, the catalytic performance showed an obvious decrease after 10 h on-stream (Fig. 9b). This obvious deactivation was probably due to the reaction not reaching equilibrium at the shorter residence time (or larger WHSV), leading to lower conversion. After 18 h on-stream, the value of WHSV changed to 4 h − 1. The results show a clear increase in catalytic activity at 20 h on-stream. However, with an increase in time-on-stream, the catalytic activity also exhibited a slight decrease, due to the reactants and products adsorbed on the surface of the catalyst, leading to less reactant accessibility of active sites, hindering the catalytic process. In order to regenerate the spent catalyst after 24 h time-on-stream, the catalyst was calcined at 500 °C in air for 2 h. The TGA data (Fig. S9) indicated that the adsorbed organic species on the spent catalyst resulted in catalyst deactivation, and during the regeneration process, they could be completely removed. The catalytic activity of the regenerated catalyst was also tested in a batch type reactor under the same reaction conditions, giving glycerol conversions in the first and second cycles of (99.7 and 99.5)%, respectively (Fig. S10). The selectivities of the 5- and 6-membered acetals were found to be (97.4 ± 1)% and (2.6 ± 1)%, respectively. The results demonstrate the potential reusability of the catalyst for industrial applications. 4 Conclusions In summary, a series of WO x /meso‑SnO2 materials was studied as solid acid catalysts for the acetalization of glycerol with acetone. Various techniques were employed to investigate the physicochemical characteristics of the WO x /meso‑SnO2 materials. Characterization results revealed that the highly dispersed WO x on the surface of meso‑SnO2 enhanced the acidic properties of the catalyst. Among the catalysts, 20 wt% WO x /meso‑SnO2 catalyst exhibited the best catalytic ability, resulting in the highest glycerol conversion (100%) and solketal selectivity (97.4%) in 2 h. Compared to the bulk-SnO2 support, mesoporous SnO2 with high surface area was beneficial to dispersing the WO x and generating the acidic sites, leading to excellent catalytic performance. Additionally, there was a slight decrease in the activity of used catalyst after several recycles in the batch-type reactor, which indicated the good reusability of the catalyst. In the continuous-flow process, 20 wt% WO x /meso‑SnO2 catalyst exhibited a stable, high glycerol conversion and solketal selectivity at WHSV = 4 h − 1, even after 24 h of time-on-stream. coredata.dc:description: Highly ordered WO x /mesoporous SnO2 (WO x /meso‑SnO2) catalysts with varying WO x loadings of (5 ∼ 20) wt% displaying excellent catalytic performance were demonstrated in the acetalization of glycerol with acetone. The synthesized catalysts were analyzed using various techniques including X-ray diffraction, N2-isotherm, electron microscopy, H2 temperature programmed reduction, raman spectroscopy, and thermogravimetric analysis. For the acetalization of glycerol with acetone, the most active catalyst was found to be WO x /meso‑SnO2 with 20 wt% WO x , and the maximum conversion of glycerol (100%) was obtained after 2 h at 20 °C, providing 97.4% selectivity (97.4% yield) for the five-membered product (solketal), due to the presence of a large number of acidic sites on the surface of the catalyst. The catalytic activity of 20 wt% WO x /meso‑SnO2 was also studied in a flow reactor. Tests were carried out at 30 °C, acetone/glycerol=30, WHSV=(4 or 8) h − 1, and atmospheric pressure for 24 h. The catalytic results showed that, when the WHSV was 4 h − 1, after 24 h of time-on-stream, both the glycerol conversion of (100 to 97.9)% and solketal yield of (97.5 to 93.6)% slightly decreased. This result suggests the potential of the 20 wt% WO x /meso‑SnO2 catalyst for the industrial acetalization of glycerol.
coredata.dc:title: Ordered WO x /mesoporous SnO2 catalysts with excellent acetalization performance for producing bio-additives from glycerol
